div1.p: To Be Named in Honor of Dr. Lazear

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
TO BE NAMED IN
HONOR OF DR. LAZEAR

Secretary Root Orders That a Bat-
tery at Fort Howard Be Called
After Brave Surgeon.

In the annual report of Secretary of War
Root which was made public yesterday
the following paragraph was included:

“The name of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, con-
tract surgeon, who voluntarily permitted
himself to be inoculated with the yellow
fever germ in order to furnish a necessary
experimental test in the course of the in-
vestigation, and who died of the disease,
should be written in the list of the martyrs
who have died in the cause of humanity. As
a slight memorial of his heroism a battery
in the coast defense fortification at Fort
Howard, Baltimore, Md., has been named
‘Battery Lazear.’”

Dr. Lazear was born in Baltimore county
in 1866. He graduated from Johns Hop-
kins University in 1889, and in 1892 re-
ceived the degree of M. D. from Columbia
University. From 1895 till 1900 he was
on the staff of the out-patient department
of the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

In 1900 he was appointed a member of
a special government commission for the
investigation of yellow fever near Havana,
and it was while fulfilling his duties in
that capacity that his sad death occurred.

It has been ascertained that the fever was
communicated by a mosquito of the
Stegomya Fasciata species when it had be-
come contaminated by biting a patient in
the fever hospital.

Dr. Lazear was bitten on August 16, but
suffered no ill effects, so that when he was
bitten again on September 13 he deliberate-
ly allowed the insect to satisfy its hunger.
On September 18 he was very ill, and died
September 25.

His heroic self-sacrifice proved the theory
that the disease was transferred by the bite
of a certain mosquito, and as a result ef-
fective sanitary regulations were taken to
drive the pest from the island.

FEILTZER, B. BOLTZER, R. BLUM-
E.

A committee composed of Drs. William
Osler, Stewart Paton and William S. Thayer,
was organized to appeal for funds to place a
bronze tablet in Dr. Lazear's memory in the
Johns Hopkins. It is now being made.

His widow at present resides at 2012
Broadway, San Francisco.
